awd_titl_txt: Catalyst Award: Exploring Free Living Nematode Microbiome through Marker Gene-Based and Shotgun Metagenomic Sequencing of Single Nematodes
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. This project at Elizabeth City State University will investigate the specific associations between nematodes and prokaryote communities in freshwater and marine ecological sites using marker gene-based and shotgun metagenomics sequencing. The project will introduce underrepresented minority students to molecular techniques, while preparing them for graduate school or entry into the STEM workforce.

Complex biological processes are carried out through interactions of biotic and abiotic components. Nematodes are ubiquitous and arguably the most diverse and numerically dominant component of the meiofauna. Their close association with the most diverse group, the prokaryotes, would play a critical role in sediment ecological processes, however, this remains largely unexplored. The goal of the project is to employ a tiered approach to investigate this association and its ecological implications in 15 nematode taxa. An initial, phylogenetically informative marker gene-based characterization will be followed by shotgun metagenomic sequence-based functional analysis. Shotgun sequence data of nematodes & associated microbial communities will be used to predict community functional potential using gene and gene family functionality of recognized associations through putative metabolite profiles. This will be in the framework of inter- and intraspecific genetic variations and community ecological relevance in freshwater and marine environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Myriad interactions significantly impact the ecological functions of living organisms. Nematodes (roundworms) are among the most diverse and numerically dominant animal groups in sediment environments. Equally important are the metabolically versatile prokaryotes (bacterial communities) that play critical roles in the sediment where nematodes reside. Despite the potential for close interactions between these groups over time, research on prokaryotic diversity and its relationships with dominant sediment-dwelling invertebrates, such as nematodes, is currently lacking.

The primary goal of our catalyst project was to investigate the largely overlooked world of nematode-microbial associations using phylogenetically informative marker gene-based community profiling. Additionally, we aimed to enhance bioinformatics capacity at Elizabeth City State University—an Historically Black College and University (HBCU)—by training undergraduate students and fostering collaboration with researchers at the Hubbard Center for Genome Studies, University of New Hampshire. These research and educational objectives align with the Principal Investigator’s long-term vision to establish robust research in eukaryotic and prokaryotic microbial ecology and biodiversity at an HBCU serving a predominantly disadvantaged, economically distressed population in northeastern North Carolina.

We collected samples from aquatic habitats in coastal North Carolina and Florida, isolating and identifying numerically dominant free-living nematodes based on their morphological features. Throughout this project, we supported three graduate students, two of whom are African American, who successfully graduated with Masters degrees in Biological Sciences from Elizabeth City State University. We also mentored three undergraduate students—one African American female at Elizabeth City State University, who earned a BS in Biology, and two others at Eastern Florida State College.

This project laid the groundwork for institutional capacity in bioinformatics at Elizabeth City State University, resulting in the development and offering of two courses (one graduate and one undergraduate). Furthermore, we established a small in-house sequencing facility, crucial for training both graduate and undergraduate students. We successfully generated 16S marker gene sequences from 150 selected individuals, creating microbial community profiles for the nematode taxa. Sequence data analysis is currently ongoing.

Challenges encountered during the project included COVID-19 pandemic-related restrictions affecting laboratory work with students, repeated malfunctions of essential laboratory equipment, limited funding for replacements, an unexpected weather-related power failure that led to the loss of a full batch of processed frozen DNA samples, and the Principal Investigator’s relocation from Elizabeth City State University to Eastern Florida State College, which required setting up a new laboratory and reassembling necessary research equipment.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2024
Modified by: Eyualem Abebe
